Taylor's ideas were particularly well-suited for Pennsylvania's burgeoning industries, such as steel and manufacturing (Kanigel, 1997, p. 60). Many companies in the state adopted his methods, leading to increased productivity and competitiveness. As a result, Pennsylvania became synonymous with industrial innovation and progress (Kanigel, 1997, p. 62). However, this drive for efficiency also had consequences. Workers faced increased pressure and scrutiny, sometimes leading to labor unrest and concerns about worker exploitation (Kanigel, 1997, p. 65). This period highlights the dual nature of Pennsylvania's industrial ambitions: while progress and efficiency brought prosperity, they also raised questions about the human cost of rapid growth.

Three Mile Island: The Crisis of Pennsylvania's Energy Dynasty

The Three Mile Island catastrophe serves as a stark reminder of the risks associated with Pennsylvania's industrial legacy. On March 28, 1979, a partial meltdown occurred at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant near Harrisburg, resulting in the release of radioactive gases (Walker, 2004, p. 108). Although there were no immediate fatalities, the incident exposed weaknesses in the nuclear industry's safety protocols and raised questions about the long-term health effects for those living nearby (Walker, 2004, p. 118).
